attributes.alt: Book cover for Please Play Safe! Penguin's Guide to Playground Safety by Margery Cuyler, illustrated by Will Hillenbrand. The cover art shows a penguin with a whistle and jump rope, a pig in a helmet riding a scooter, and a giraffe carrying a jump rope in its mouth.

elements.text: Use Circle Time Review the letters
sing a song about playing, and introduce vocabulary word
Begin Story Time by introducing book and asking,
What does Penguin want his friends to do at the playground?
Check for understanding, differentiating as needed.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Use information to compare and contrast; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Begin to experiment with end punctuation.
Identify their own bodies within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Help children practice letter-sound correspondence,  focusing on the letters
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Who are the characters in the story? How do they play safely?
What playground toy will you pretend to use? What will you do to play safe?
How many playground toys are there? How do you know?
What can you write about playing on a slide?
What materials will you use to show the right way to use a slide?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Use blocks to build a fun slide. How tall will you build it?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about when the animals are moving carefully.
Use information to compare and contrast; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Begin to experiment with end punctuation.
Identify their own bodies within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Exercise good habits of personal safety.
Guide children in practicing taking turns.
Ask children questions they will all want to answer.
Roll a ball to one child at a time. Only the child with the ball can answer.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
How do the characters in the story take turns?
Show me how you wait in line for a turn. Can you talk to a friend while you wait in line?
Can you name three playground toys where friends wait in line?
Have you ever been on a see-saw? Show me how it looked!
Make a picture of two friends on a see-saw.
Show me how you can write the letter
and make a new toy for the playground.
Can you build a see-saw? What materials will you use?

Draw a picture of a helmet you would like to wear.
? How can you decorate your letter with some noodles?
Can you build a helmet to stay safe? Which materials would you use? Why?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas page for Five Little Froggies Jumping on a Bed. There are six pictures of frogs on a bed. The captions explain each picture: Five little froggies jumping on a bed; Four little froggies jumping on a bed; Three little froggies jumping on a bed; Two little froggies jumping on a bed; One little froggy jumping on a bed; and, finally, Mom comes in and says "No more froggies jumping on the bed."

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  Five Little Froggies Jumping
Use Circle Time to talk about playing safely, count backwards, and introduce vocabulary words
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Begin to experiment with end punctuation.

Ask children to create and decorate their stick puppets.
Invite them to act out the song and count the puppets.
Talk about why following rules is important.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Compare this book to other books you have read. How are they alike? Different?
What happens to the froggies after they are all hurt? Can you act that out?
Build a seesaw with Connecting Cubes. How many did you use?
Think about what might happen if the froggies jump on the bed again. Can you write about it?
Make a puppet of Mama or  the doctor.
Think about the sound you hear at the beginning of
Think about how you might build a bed that would be safe for the froggies. How high would the bed be?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the playground, act out a story, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
Which safety lesson do you think is the most important and why?
Share and repeat the details in a text; relate own experiences to those in books.
Begin to experiment with end punctuation.
Identify their own bodies within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Which safety lesson do you think is the most important and why?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Which book would you like a friend to read? Tell why.
You are Penguin on the playground. What will you say  to your friends?
Create a picture of your favorite playground toy.
Pretend you will write a book about playing safe. Which playground equipment would you use as an example? Why?
What sound do you hear at the end of
? Can you write that letter using sticks or play clay?
What end mark goes at the end of a sentence? Can you draw one?
Imagine that you get to build a playground toy! What would you build? How would you build it?
